properties.label:
Imperial ships receive 30% less damage than normal.
If destroyed, the player ship respawns at an Imperial shipyard and no items are lost.
This is the recommended setting for players unused to this type of game.

This mode disables respawning for the player and considerably increases the chance of high-end drops.
Sectors can receive increased reinforcements from the very start.
The true challenge of an Imperial Captain in a merciless galaxy.

Imperial ships take normal damage from hostiles.
If destroyed, the player's ship respawns at an Imperial shipyard. However, there is a chance you might lose any modules found since your last visit to a shipyard.
Enables contextual tips to explain the mechanics of HEXTERMINATE.

A once great Empire strives to reclaim its glorious past, but its enemies are many and powerful.

Lead your fleet in a story-led Campaign to reclaim the galaxy. This is the recommended start if you are new to HEXTERMINATE.

A new game mode with endless progression.

This mode is currently in development and not yet available.

For more advanced players, Infinite War is a customisable, procedurally generated galaxy with an additional faction, new modules and a modified ruleset.

You should play with tips enabled if this is your first Infinite War playthrough.

An assault gunship with a nearly barbaric design, the Ironclad relies on its multiple layers of heavy armour and rocket launchers in order to present a devastating forward section. 

Its lack of lateral armour does make it vulnerable to flanking.

The Lancer is a fast skirmisher gunship which uses its superior speed and range to stay one step ahead of hostile forces while harassing them with relative impunity.

However, its light armour does limit its usefulness in close combat.

Proven time and time again, the Phalanx gunship is a powerful ship with an easily extensible design.

Balanced even if with a limited range, it has a staying power that makes it extremely reliable.
Press the Left Mouse button to start firing the turrets, and then again to stop firing. By default this option is off and your turrets fire while you're holding down the button.
Displays a coloured outline around all ships, making it easier to distinguish the player ship from friendlies and hostiles.

Toggles various post-processing effects.
Disabling post-processing decreases visual fidelity, but may increase performance on lower end machines.
